subject: Re: Does Static Invocation call setUp()/tearDown()?
msgSnippet: ... It does not keep them from being invoked, but they only get invoked once per TestCase, not before and after each test method. Perhaps I was not clear when
messageBody:
Vladimir R. Bossicard wrote:
>>However a question came up recently that if you specify the
>>tests by overriding the runTest() method as below (static
>>invocation), that setUp() and tearDown() do not get called
>>for every method, but only get called once.
>
> I don't see why on earth you would write a test by overwriting runTest,
> but let's take that as an example.
>
> If you take a look at the TestCase class, you'll notice that it's in
> fact runBare that calls setUp/tearDown:
>
> public void runBare() throws Throwable {
> setUp();
> try {
> runTest();
> }
> finally {
> tearDown();
> }
> }
>
> runTest is only executing _one single_ method of the TestCase object.
> Creating a TestCase like you do [new MyTest("Testing runTest()")] is
> wrong (in a normal case). The name passed to the TestCase is originally
> the name of the test method that will be executed.
>
> so you see that overwriting runTest will not prevent the setUp and
> tearDown methods to be invoked.

It does not keep them from being invoked, but they only get invoked
once per TestCase, not before and after each test method. Perhaps I
was not clear when I stated what I was looking for. I want the behavior
that is:

setUp() -> first test -> tearDown()
setUp() -> next test -> tearDown()
...
setUp() -> last test -> tearDown()

But overriding runTest() produces:

setUp() -> first test -> next test -> last test -> tearDown()

Only calling setUp() once before all testXXX() methods, and
tearDown() once after all testXXX() methods. The JUnit 3.8.1
JavaDoc for TestCase shows the overriding of runTest(), as well
as at least one of the other HTML files in the doc/ directory
of the 3.8.1 download (I don't remember which one off hand).

I did see the TestCase source you mention above for runBare(),
but as usual it didn't register to me quite the way it did when
you put it here, isolated from the rest of the class. Don't you
just love pair programming? <G>

I think I have figured out how this is supposed to work regarding
overriding runTest(). To get setUp()/tearDown() called once per test
method, only one test method should be added to runTest(), but use
of suite() is required to make this behavior fluid.

As far as the name passed to the TestCase not being the test method
name, that does work as in my example, if you override runTest().
The test method name can be passed to the constructor to invoke a
single test method by the programmer, or by the framework when it
is executing a TestSuite. At least that's what I see in the source
and when running in the debugger.

Once again, lest y'all think I'm completely nuts, I wasn't advocating
this approach, just trying to understand the behavior since it is
both possible and documented in the JUnit files.

Thanks for all the help. Sorry for bogging things down with this
somewhat off the wall question.
--
Thanks,
